block.p: California Short of Power In an Age of Deregulation Four years after it led the nation into a deregulation of the electric industry, California is at the brink of a breakdown in its power supply. The nation's most populous state nearly ran out of power for the third consecutive day.

What disturbs California utility executives and regulators is that this week's crisis has come even though none of the state's power plants or transmission lines has failed, at a time when temperatures around the state have been hot but hardly extraordinary. The state's power supply simply can no longer keep up with peak demand, they warn. [Page A1.]

Proxy Companies Plan to Merge Georgeson Shareholder Communications, the world's largest proxy solicitation company, will announce today that it has acquired Corporate Investor Communications, the third-largest concern in the industry. [C6.]

Adviser to Celebrities Pleads Guilty Dana C. Giacchetto, the money manager who promised Hollywood stars and other artists a safe investment haven, pleaded guilty to fraud and acknowledged that he misappropriated some of his clients' money. Mr. Giacchetto, 37, faces 46 to 57 months in prison and a fine of $10,000 to $100,000, as well as restitution payments to fraud victims. [C2.]

Nasdaq Falls in Flight to Blue Chips The Nasdaq composite index slumped as skittish investors sought safety in blue-chip stocks or headed for the sidelines waiting for tomorrow's report on the job market in July. The Nasdaq composite fell 27.06 points, or 0.7 percent, to 3,658.46. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 80.58 points, or 0.8 percent, to 10,687.53. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 0.60 point, to 1,438.70. [C8.]

30-Year Bond Receives a Reprieve In announcing the details of its quarterly auction of Treasury notes and bonds, the government did not put the 30-year bond on the endangered species list, surprising some investors. The yield of the 30-year bond rose to 5.76 percent from 5.72 percent. The yield on the 10-year note fell to 5.97 percent from 5.98 percent. [C8.]
Snapple Creates a Line of Candy Snapple Beverages, a unit of Triarc, is bringing its unusual flavors to a line of Snapple candy this fall. Advertising. [C6.]
Book Publishers in Deal to Combine Harry N. Abrams agreed to pay about $6 million to acquire the assets of Stewart, Tabori & Chang, combining two prominent publishers of illustrated books. [C6.]

New-Home Sales Fell 3.7% in June Sales of new homes fell 3.7 percent in June, to the lowest level in two and a half years, government figures showed. And in a separate report, the Conference Board said its index of leading economic indicators -- a gauge of economic performance over the next six to nine months -- was unchanged in June, the third consecutive month without an increase. [C7.]

AOL Is Sued Over Blocked E-Mail Harris Interactive, the online market research company, has filed a suit against America Online and other e-mail providers, contending those companies unlawfully blocked e-mail from Harris to its survey participants. [C7.]

Maybe the Market Can Be Beaten In the 1970's, the efficient-markets hypothesis was an article of near-religious faith, arguing that financial markets processed new information about securities so efficiently that you couldn't beat the market. Now a growing number of economists argue that the financial markets do not appear all that efficient after all. Jeff Madrick: Economic Scene. [C2.]
